channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Cyberattack on Hong Kong Vote Was Among Largest Ever, Security Chief Says
item.description: The distributed denial-of-service attack commanded a network of compromised computers around the world in an apparent attempt to overwhelm polling on Hong Kong’s political future.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG

item.title: Aid Scarce as Pakistanis Flee Conflict
item.description: At least 200,000 Pakistani civilians have fled a combat zone in North Waziristan since the government began an offensive against militants.
item.dc:creator: By IHSANULLAH TIPU MEHSUD
item.media:description: Pakistani children stand in a partially destroyed building in Bannu on Friday, after fleeing the North Waziristan region.

item.title: Iraq Insurgents Reaping Wealth as They Advance
item.description: Behind the image of savagery that the extremists of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria present lies a disciplined organization that employs social media and sophisticated financial strategies.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shiite relatives on Friday wept over the coffin of an Iraqi soldier killed in Mosul by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

item.title: Sunni Muslim and Baathist Forces Said to Clash Near Kirkuk
item.description: In a split in the coalition of Sunni Muslim forces supporting the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, the militants clashed with an Iraqi Baathist faction allied with them, Iraqi security officials said on Saturday.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: As Ukraine Announces Cease-Fire, White House Points Finger at Russia
item.description: The Obama administration said Moscow was continuing to covertly arm rebels in the eastern part of Ukraine, despite its denials.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: The line on Friday to cross into Russia from Izvaryne, Ukraine. Russia has complained about demands that it tighten control of its border with Ukraine.

item.title: World Briefing: China: Police Kill 13 in Attack in Xinjiang Region
item.description: Police officers shot dead 13 attackers on Saturday who rammed a vehicle into the main police station in the region of Xinjiang, according to media reports.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Quick History: In Refugee Statistics, a Stark Tale of Global Strife
item.description: The number of people around the world forced by conflict to flee their homes is at its highest number since World War II.
item.dc:creator: By SERGE SCHMEMANN
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: A refugee camp in Khazer, Iraq, expanded rapidly last week as families fled Mosul.

item.title: U.N. Reports Sharp Increase in Refugees as Civil Wars Cripple Nations
item.description: More than 51 million people have been displaced by violence around the world, according to the head of the United Nations refugee agency.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Displaced residents of Mosul, Iraq, receiving food aid this week.

item.title: Iraq’s Hold on Border Crossings Weakening as at Least 34 Are Killed in Battle
item.description: Sunni militants overran one of the last government-held crossings on the Syrian border on Friday after a fierce battle that left at least 34 Iraqi soldiers dead.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and DURAID ADNAN
item.media:credit: Ayman Oghanna for The New York Times
item.media:description: Men volunteering to join the Iraqi Army at a recruitment center in Baghdad on Friday.

item.title: U.N. Chief Served Papers in Suit by Haitian Victims, Lawyers Say
item.description: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon’s spokesman denied that the official had been served.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Presbyterians Vote to Divest Holdings to Pressure Israel
item.description: The church voted at its general convention to divest from three companies that it says supply Israel with equipment used in the occupation of Palestinian territory.
item.dc:creator: By LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.media:credit: Joshua Lott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert Ross, center, and other observers in Detroit after the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) voted Friday to approve divestment.

item.title: As Ukraine Announces Cease-Fire, White House Points Finger at Russia
item.description: The Obama administration said Moscow was continuing to covertly arm rebels in the eastern part of Ukraine, despite its denials.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Pro-Russian troops in tanks driving toward Donetsk on Friday.

item.title: World Briefing: Syria: Bomb Kills More Than 30 Near a Central City
item.description: A powerful truck bomb exploded on Friday in a government-held village in central Syria, killing more than 30 civilians and wounding dozens more, the state news agency SANA and opposition activists said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Afghan Leader Backs U.N. Election Role
item.description: President Hamid Karzai’s comments revived the possibility that the international community might once more have a hand in the selection of a new leader for Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: World Briefing: The Vatican: Pope Denounces Legalization of Drugs
item.description: Pope Francis on Friday condemned the legalization of recreational drugs as a flawed and failed experiment.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistan: Gruesome Murder Resembles a Case in India
item.description: The police said Friday that a 20-year-old woman was gang-raped, killed and hanged from a tree in Pakistan in a case with a chilling resemblance to a double rape and murder that caused outrage in India last month.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Missing Israeli Teenagers Revive a Mother’s Hard-Earned Intimacy With Loss
item.description: For Sherri Mandell, whose son was killed in the West Bank more than a decade ago, the kidnapping of three Israeli teenagers feels all too familiar.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sherri Mandell and her husband, Seth, a rabbi, head a foundation in their son's name that runs camps for children who have lost relatives and support groups for bereaved mothers.

item.title: World Cup 2014: In Porto Alegre, a More Dour Soccer Culture
item.description: The two main clubs in Porto Alegre have a reputation for playing the Uruguayan and Argentine way: tough, and without restraint.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREAS CAMPOMAR
item.media:description: Fans watching the World Cup match between Australia and the Netherlands in Porto Alegre. The locals have a more dour, realistic view of soccer than many Brazilians.

item.title: Afghan President, in Reversal, Backs U.N. Role to Settle Election Dispute
item.description: President Hamid Karzai’s comments revived the possibility that the international community might once more have a hand in the selection of a new leader for Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: Toughest Issues Still Unresolved in Iran Nuclear Talks
item.description: A month from the deadline for a final accord, negotiators have a tentative draft, but the United States and Iran remain far apart on difficult issues.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Bits Blog: Canadian Judge Says Google Must Remove Links Worldwide
item.description: The temporary order, granted last Friday by the Supreme Court of British Columbia, emerged from protracted litigation between two companies that were once closely connected.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Google has argued that following a global order by a Canadian court to remove specific search results could put in into conflict with laws of other countries.

item.title: Deep in the Amazon, an Isolated Village Tunes In to the World Cup
item.description: The fevered grip of the world’s largest sporting event can be felt even in some of the most isolated areas of the rain forest, where outsiders seldom visit.
item.dc:creator: By JERÉ LONGMAN
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: The decks of the PP Maués were crisscrossed with hammocks for an overnight trip down the Amazon.

item.title: Saying No to Austerity, Spain Unveils Tax Cuts
item.description: The government has approved plans to cut company and income taxes in 2015 and 2016 in a bid to bolster spending and investment.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Pope Condemns Legalization of Recreational Drugs
item.description: Pope Francis condemned the legalization of recreational drugs as a flawed and failed experiment as he lent his voice Friday to a debate that is raging from the United States to Uruguay.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Japanese Report Casts Doubt on Admission of Wartime Sexual Coercion
item.description: A new report questioned the factual accuracy of a landmark apology to women forced to work in military brothels in World War II, a finding that could worsen tensions with South Korea.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
